title: The intersection of medical and confessional discourse is apparent in the canons of Lateran IV. While Canon 21 makes use of Christus medicus to describe how confessors should operate in relation to confessants, Canon 22 references medical practice, mandating that physicians call for a confessor before beginning treatment. Contact would seem to be immediate by definition. Aristotle argued that it is not so: in fact, he maintains, an interval always separates that which touches from that which is touched, and it alone allows for the possibility of sensation
